By the middle of 1939, it was clear to many Jews in Central Europe that they were no longer safe in their own homes and workplaces.
The annexation of Austria and Czechoslovakia, alongside a vicious pogrom in November 1938, prompted many Jews to flee the German Reich.
This was no easy task, since few countries around the world were willing to accept them.
Some, however, managed to escape to Britain and to Wales.
